text: People like Gary make arguments that are based on the presupposition that government spending is all well spent and at maximum efficiency. text:
Basically, tax fairly and encourage people to earn more. 

Assets are already taxed - you pay tax when you buy a house, a car etc. youâ€™re taxed monthly on those assets (council tax, road fund license, fuel duty etc). Then VAT on day-to-day purchases. 


Trying to tax more assets is difficult because it assumes the asset has an objective worth - assets donâ€™t have objective worth - something is only as expensive as what someone is willing to pay for it. If something is thought to be so expensive it has a tax liability on it then no one will want it and the value will go down. Thatâ€™s why tax is taken at the transaction level when an objective amount of real money changes hands. 

Everyoneâ€™s argument about taxing the rich seems to be because they donâ€™t like the idea of people being rich (or super rich)

text: Taxing the ultra-rich by one or two percent would make no material difference to their lives. They wouldn't miss a single meal, party or holiday, but instead we're looking to cut benefits. Now some are working the benefit system to their advantage but most need this money to survive. The Conservatives were thorough in raising the bar to qualify so if you're on benefits now then you definitely need them. But I suppose people on benefits don't donate tens or hundreds of thousands of pounds to political parties or fund lucrative speaking events for our politicians.

text:
He's right in his intentions. I would change the millionaires to multi-millionaires. 

I'm not a millionaire but spending 5 mil a year is easy. But for people earning more than 10 mil a year, they don't really care how much of their profits are taxed. But taxing assets, I don't agree with. It punishes savers and savers shouldn't be punished.
